description:
Human papillomavirus type 6b (HPV-6b) is a virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family, specifically the genus Alphapapillomavirus. It is one of the most common types of human papillomaviruses, primarily associated with the development of benign genital warts (condylomata acuminata) in both males and females.

HPV-6b is a non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a circular genome of approximately 7,900 base pairs. The viral genome encodes several essential proteins, including the early proteins (E1, E2, E6, and E7) involved in viral replication and transcription, as well as the late proteins (L1 and L2) that form the viral capsid.

The virus primarily infects the basal epithelial cells of the skin and mucous membranes, where it can establish a persistent infection. Infection with HPV-6b can lead to the formation of soft, fleshy, and potentially disfiguring warts on the genitalia, anus, and surrounding areas. These warts are typically harmless, but in rare cases, they may cause discomfort or interfere with normal bodily functions.

While HPV-6b is not considered a high-risk type for the development of cervical cancer, it is often included in the analysis of HPV infections and can be detected using molecular diagnostic techniques, such as DNA-based tests or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays.
